generated_text: The structure of hydrate is of great interest to the petroleum industry, as it can provide information about the formation conditions of oil and gas reservoirs. In this work, we report the structure of neon hydrate, which is the first example of a hydrate with a guest that is not a conventional molecule.

The mathematical foundations of quantum theory are a matter of intense debate. The most prominent reconstruction programs are due to von Neumann, Mackey, Jauch, Piron, Abramsky, and Coecke. They all attempt to provide a categorical foundation for quantum theory, but the axioms used by different authors are not equivalent. We provide a common set of axioms that are purely categorical and do not presuppose any analytical structure. This addresses a question about the foundations of quantum theory raised in the 1970s by von Neumann and revived in the 2010s by Abramsky and Coecke. Our work is also relevant to the foundations of mathematics in general.

The Myxozoa are a group of microscopic parasites that cause diseases in a wide range of hosts, including humans. The evolutionary origin of the Myxozoa has been elusive, and a close relationship with cnidarians, a group that includes corals, sea anemones, jellyfish, and hydroids, is supported by some phylogenetic studies. Here, we show that the Myxozoa are a sister group to the cnidarians, and we provide evidence for the extreme reduction in gene content and genome size that is characteristic of the Myxozoa. Our results suggest that the degeneration of the myxozoan body plan from a free-living cnidarian to a microscopic parasitic cnidarian was accompanied by a reduction in genome size and gene content. This is a major evolutionary transition, and our results may provide insights into the origins of parasitism. (Show more)

COVID-19, caused by SARS-CoV-2, is a global pandemic that has caused millions of deaths worldwide. One of the hallmarks of this disease is the dysregulation of the host immune response, which is characterized by the down-regulation of type I IFNs and the consequent impairment of the antiviral innate immune response. In this study, we show that SARS-CoV-2 is able to block the nuclear import of type I IFNs, which is a mechanism of viral antagonism that has not been described before. Our results provide a mechanism of viral antagonism that could be used by SARS-CoV-2 to evade the antiviral action of type I IFNs. This mechanism could be used as a target for the development of new antiviral strategies. (Show more)

The proton channel Hv1 is involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zn2+ is an important physiological inhibitor of Hv1, but the molecular mechanism of how Zn2+ inhibits Hv1 is not completely understood. We use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of Hv1. We find that Zn2+ binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the Hv1 channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. Mutations of some Hv1 residues affect only Zn2+ inhibition of the voltage sensor motion, whereas mutations of other residues also affect Zn2+ inhibition of gate opening. These effects are similar in monomeric and dimeric Hv1 channels, suggesting that the Zn2+-binding sites are localized within each subunit of the Hv1 dimer. Elucidating the molecular mechanism of how Zn2+ inhibits Hv1 will further our understanding of Hv1 function and might provide valuable information for future drug development for Hv1 channels. The world will need to produce more food to feed the 10 billion people expected by 2050. We show that, absent changes in temperature variability or breeding gains in heat tolerance, the coefficient of variation of maize yields will increase in all major maize-producing and -exporting countries, and the probability of simultaneous production losses greater than 10% in any given year will increase. These results highlight the need for investments in breeding for heat tolerance.

The extent to which large mammalian herbivores partition food resources is largely unknown because of the difficulty of species-level diet identification. We used DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet breadth, composition, and overlap for seven abundant African LMH species. These species ranged from almost-exclusive grazers to almost-exclusive browsers, and dietary overlap was greatest between species that were similar in body size and proportional grass consumption. Nonetheless, diet composition differed between all species—even pairs of grazers matched in size, digestive physiology, and location—and dietary similarity was sometimes greater across grazing and browsing guilds than within them. Such taxonomically fine-grained diet partitioning suggests that coarse trophic categorizations may generate misleading conclusions about competition and coexistence in LMH assemblages, and that LMH diversity may be more tightly linked to plant diversity than is currently recognized. We conducted a large survey of small businesses to understand the impact of the COVID-19 crisis on their operations. We find that many businesses have already laid off or closed, and that the length of the crisis is negatively associated with the expected duration of business closures. We also find that many small businesses are financially fragile, with only about 2 wk of cash on hand at the time of the survey. Finally, we find that many small businesses plan to apply for the CARES Act loans, but anticipate problems with accessing the program.

Plastic debris is one of the most visible consequences of human activities in the ocean. However, the magnitude of the problem is still unclear. We show that the global load of floating plastic debris is on the order of tens of thousands of tons, far less than expected. Our observations of the size distribution of floating plastic debris point at important size-selective sinks removing millimeter-sized fragments of floating plastic on a large scale. This sink may involve a combination of fast nano-fragmentation of the microplastic into particles of microns or smaller, their transference to the ocean interior by food webs and ballasting processes, and processes yet to be discovered. Resolving the fate of the missing plastic debris is of fundamental importance to determine the nature and significance of the impacts of plastic pollution in the ocean. View Full-Text

The origin of the solar system is one of the most important questions in astronomy. We determined the ages of 40 large silicon carbide grains from the Murchison meteorite, which were formed in the interstellar medium. We found that the grains have ages of 3.9 ± 1.6 Ma to ∼3 ± 2 Ga, which is consistent with the age of the solar system. We also found that the grains have a majority of interstellar lifetimes of <300 Ma, which is shorter than theoretical estimates for large grains. This indicates that the grains condensed in outflows of asymptotic giant branch stars <4.9 Ga ago that possibly formed during an episode of enhanced star formation ∼7 Ga ago. We also found that the grains acquired the bulk of their cosmogenic nuclides in the interstellar medium and not by exposure to an enhanced particle flux of the early active sun. These results provide important constraints for the formation of the solar system.

The global fishing fleet has doubled in size since 1950, and the motorized fleet has increased by a factor of 10. The powered-artisanal fleet has grown by a factor of 100, and the industrial fleet by a factor of 10. The powered-artisanal fleet is the most numerous, but the industrial fleet is the most powerful. The powered-artisanal fleet has been the main driver of the expansion of the global fleet, and the effective CPUE has decreased by a fifth since 1950. The effective CPUE of most countries in 2015 was a fifth of its 1950s value, which was compared with a global decline in abundance. There are signs, however, of stabilization and more effective management in recent years, which could help to reduce the pressure on ocean resources.

The ability to increase the energy available to the mother is a key factor in the evolution of all forms of care and domestication. Here, we show that the increase in energy is the primary driver of the increase in reproductive output. We also show that the increase in energy is not the result of an increase in resource availability.

Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a sporadic neurodegenerative disorder that is characterized by the accumulation of alpha-synuclein (α-syn) aggregates in oligodendrocytes. We show here that the inflammatory protease caspase-1, which is activated in the brain in response to inflammation, is also able to cleave the C terminus of α-syn, leading to its aggregation. We also show that the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765 is able to reduce the load of α-syn aggregates in a mouse model of MSA. Finally, we show that VX-765 is able to limit the neurotoxic effects of α-syn aggregation in this mouse model. These results suggest that VX-765 could be a promising candidate for the treatment of MSA.

The endothelium is the lining of the blood vessels and is the most abundant cell type in the body. It is responsible for controlling the exchange of oxygen, nutrients, and waste products between the blood and the tissues. The endothelium is composed of a single layer of cells and is responsible for controlling the contractility of the blood vessels, controlling the clotting of the blood, and controlling inflammation. The endothelium is a complex system that is composed of thousands of specialized cells that are connected to each other in a network. This network is responsible for integrating the multitude of signals that are received from the blood and the tissues. This paper provides a detailed description of the structure of the endothelial network and the nature of the communication between the cells. The findings of this paper will help to understand the structure and function of the endothelium and will provide a foundation for future studies of the endothelium.

The COVID-19 pandemic has generated enormous data challenges. We describe the design and implementation of the COVIDcast API, a data source that provides open access to many auxiliary indicators of COVID-19 activity, including signals extracted from deidentified medical claims data, massive online surveys, cell phone mobility data, and internet search trends. These are available at a fine geographic resolution (mostly at the county level) and are updated daily. The data are available through the API and accompanying R and Python software packages. This paper describes the data sources and signals, and provides examples demonstrating that the auxiliary signals in the COVIDcast API present information relevant to tracking COVID activity, augmenting traditional public health reporting and empowering research and decision-making. We hope that the COVIDcast API will be useful to researchers, health policy makers, and the general public. We welcome feedback and suggestions for improvement. The data are available at https://github.com/COVIDcast/covidcast-api. The software is available at https://github.com/COVIDcast/covidcast-api-r and https://github.com/COVIDcast/covidcast-api-python.

The selectivity filter and the activation gate in potassium channels are functionally and structurally coupled. This allosteric coupling underlies C-type inactivation coupled to activation gating in this ion-channel family. We have identified the second Threonine residue within the TTVGYGD signature sequence of K+ channels as a crucial residue for this allosteric communication. A Threonine to Alanine substitution at this position was studied in three representative members of the K+-channel family. Interestingly, all of the mutant channels exhibited lack of C-type inactivation gating and an inversion of their allosteric coupling (i.e., closing of the activation gate collapses the channel’s selectivity filter). A state-dependent crystallographic study of KcsA-T75A proves that, on activation, the selectivity filter transitions from a nonconductive and deep C-type inactivated conformation to a conductive one. Finally, we provide a crystallographic demonstration that closed-state inactivation can be achieved by the structural collapse of the channel’s selectivity filter. This work provides a structural explanation for the functional coupling between the activation gate and the selectivity filter. The gut microbiome is a complex ecosystem that is thought to play a role in the health of the host. However, the role of the microbiome in the health of the host is not well understood. One of the ways that the microbiome may influence the host is through the production of natural products. Natural products are a diverse class of compounds that are produced by a variety of organisms. In this study, we investigate the potential of anaerobic fungi to produce natural products.

Social dominance is a fundamental aspect of social behavior, but the role of personality traits in the establishment of social hierarchies is poorly understood. Here we show that anxiety, a personality trait that predisposes individuals to become subordinate in dyadic encounters, is associated with reduced mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens. We further show that the low probability to become dominant in high-anxious animals is due to a reduction in mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens, and that this is reversed by nicotinamide, a vitamin B3 compound that enhances brain energy metabolism. Our findings highlight the importance of brain energy metabolism in social behavior and point to mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens as a potential marker and avenue of treatment for anxiety-related social disorders. This paper presents a systematic approach to design and manufacture multifunctional structures that can be used to achieve any desired mechanical response under large deformation. The proposed approach is based on the synthesis of multimaterial composite structures and their heteroassembly into complex architectures. The synthesized structures are digitally designed to have distinct material phases with different behaviors, which are seamlessly integrated to produce the target responses. The structures are manufactured via multimaterial fabrication, and their highly nonlinear responses are physically and accurately realized in experiments. The proposed approach can be used to design multifunctional structures with complex shapes and behaviors for a wide range of applications.

Hemoglobin is the oxygen-carrying protein of red blood cells. The hemoglobin gene is one of the most highly expressed genes in the human body. The hemoglobin gene is also one of the most variable, with the ability to produce a wide range of hemoglobin variants. The hemoglobin variants are important in the study of hemoglobin function and in the study of hemoglobin diseases. In this study, we show that the heterochronic let-7 miRNA pathway is active in human erythroid tissues, and we show that the insulin-like growth factor 2 mRNA-binding protein 1 (IGF2BP1) is a key player in the regulation of hemoglobin expression.

Cancer is a leading cause of death worldwide, and the development of new therapies is urgently needed. In this study, we identified a mechanism of resistance to ferroptosis, a form of regulated necrosis driven by iron-dependent lipid peroxidation, in cancer cells with mutations in the PI3K-AKT-mTOR pathway. This resistance is mediated by the activation of sterol regulatory element-binding protein 1/stearoyl-CoA desaturase-1-dependent lipogenesis, which is a mechanism of ferroptosis suppression. We also show that this mechanism can be overcome by targeting the PI3K-AKT-mTOR pathway and ferroptosis inducer. These findings have implications for the development of new therapies for cancer. Hypertension is the most common cause of heart failure, and the treatment of hypertension is the most important strategy for the prevention of heart failure. However, the treatment of hypertension is often complicated by the development of heart failure. The treatment of hypertension is also complicated by the development of cardiovascular remodeling, which is a major cause of heart failure. We show that the treatment of hypertension with the widely used class of drugs for treating hypertension, the L-type Ca2+ channel blockers, promotes cardiovascular remodeling through activation of the Ca2+ sensor STIM. Our findings may help to explain the development of heart failure in patients treated with L-type Ca2+ channel blockers and may lead to the development of new strategies for the treatment of heart failure. The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy that changed the management of 10 million hectares of federal forest in the Pacific Northwest. We show that the NWFP halted the decline of bird populations associated with early-seral forests, but not older forests. We also show that the NWFP failed to halt the decline of older-forest–associated bird populations, which are still declining. Our findings highlight the importance of continuing to prioritize older forests under the NWFP and the need to ensure that the creation of early-seral ecosystems does not impede the conservation and development of older-forest structure.

Antibiotic resistance is a major threat to global health. In this work, we present a computational approach to design new antibiotics. The design strategy is based on the prediction of the solubility, membrane permeability, and binding affinity of acylide antibiotics. We show that the best candidate designed by us is more active than telithromycin, a clinically used antibiotic, and is up to 56 times more active than the most potent compound in the literature. The best compounds designed by us show activity, especially when combined with the membrane-weakening drug colistin, against Acinetobacter baumanii, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and Escherichia coli, which are the three most critical targets from the priority list of pathogens of the World Health Organization. The design strategy presented in this work can be used to develop new antibiotics against other pathogens. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

We introduce a new deep learning architecture that is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters. The architecture is based on a simple idea: use dilated convolutions to capture features at different scales, and densely connect all feature maps with each other. The resulting architecture is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters and consists of a single set of operations, making it easier to implement, train, and apply in practice. We compare results of the proposed network architecture with popular existing architectures for several segmentation problems, showing that the proposed architecture is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters, with a reduced risk of overfitting the training data. We believe that the proposed architecture will be useful for many image-processing problems in the future.

The transport of moisture in the tropics is a critical process for the global energy budget and on geologic timescales, has markedly influenced continental landscapes, migratory pathways, and biological evolution. We present a continuous, first-of-its-kind 1.3-My record of continental hydroclimate and lake-level variability derived from drill core data from Lake Malawi, East Africa. We observe dramatic shifts in effective moisture, resulting in large-scale changes in one of the world’s largest lakes and most diverse freshwater ecosystems. Results show evidence for 24 lake level drops of more than 200 m during the Late Quaternary, including 15 lowstands when water levels were more than 400 m lower than modern. A dramatic shift is observed at the Mid-Pleistocene Transition (MPT), consistent with far-field climate forcing, which separates vastly different hydroclimate regimes before and after 800,000 years ago. Before 800 ka, lake levels were lower, indicating a climate drier than today, and water levels changed frequently. Following the MPT high-amplitude lake level variations dominate the record. The use of electronic devices in the hours before bedtime has become ubiquitous. This study shows that reading an electronic book on a light-emitting device (LE-eBook) for 1 h before bedtime has important effects on sleep, including a delayed circadian clock, reduced melatonin levels, and reduced alertness the next morning. These effects are likely due to the light emitted by the LE-eBook, which has been shown to have alerting effects, suppress melatonin, and phase-shift the biological clock. This study highlights the importance of the biological effects of light on sleep and the need for further research on the impact of electronic devices on sleep and health. (PsycINFO Database Record

The Younger Dryas cooling is a well-known event in the Earth sciences, but the cause of the cooling is still debated. One of the most widely accepted hypotheses is that one or more bolide impacts triggered the cooling. We show that the osmium isotope composition of the Younger Dryas ejecta is consistent with the hypothesis that the cooling was triggered by an impact.

CTLA-4 is a key regulator of T cell activation, but its role in the development of autoimmunity is not fully understood. Here, we show that CTLA-4 is essential for the development of autoimmunity, but its role in the development of autoimmunity is not fully understood.

Beetles are the most speciose group of animals, but the evolutionary history of this order remains poorly understood. We used the most comprehensive dataset of beetle genomes to resolve the evolutionary history of this group, and to trace the evolution of genes enabling the digestion of plant cell walls. Our results suggest that the evolution of beetles was driven by multiple factors, including low extinction rates over a long evolutionary history, codiversification with angiosperms, and the convergent acquisition of genes encoding enzymes that enable the digestion of plant cell walls.

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against such variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. We anticipate that our approach will be useful for other protein molecules, including vaccines and other therapeutics. We report the results of a large-scale experiment that investigates the extent to which larger populations enhance cumulative cultural evolution. We find that larger populations do not enhance the performance of paper planes, but that the size of the population does affect the variation in plane performance.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia and the fifth leading cause of death in the United States. The strongest genetic risk factor influencing susceptibility to AD is the APOE gene. APOE isoform is highly associated with AD risk, and the presence of two copies of the APOE4 allele increases risk by ∼12-fold. We found that APOE isoform is highly important in regulating the rate of astrocytic phagocytosis, which is a major process in normal synapse pruning and turnover. APOE2 enhances the rate of phagocytosis, whereas APOE4 decreases it. These studies suggest that APOE4 may be associated with defective phagocytic capacity of astrocytes, which may accelerate the rate of accumulation of senescent synapses and enhance their vulnerability to classical-complement-cascade mediated neurodegeneration. This hypothesis may help to explain the increased risk of AD associated with APOE4. Further studies are needed to test this hypothesis. (PsycINFO Database Record

The Earth's inner core is a solid sphere with a diameter of 2,890 km, which is the fastest rotating object in the solar system. The inner core is a unique natural laboratory for studying the physics of solid-state materials. However, the formation mechanism of the inner core is still a mystery. We show that the nucleation of the inner core is likely to be a two-step process, which is different from the conventional view. This mechanism reduces the required undercooling of iron nucleation, which provides a key factor in solving the inner core nucleation paradox. The two-step nucleation scenario of the inner core also opens an avenue for understanding the structure and anisotropy of the present inner core. Our study provides a new perspective for the study of the inner core and other solids. View Full-Text

Marijuana is the most commonly used illicit drug in the United States. Although the effects of marijuana on the brain are well known, the effects of chronic marijuana use on the brain are not. Here, we show that the brain DA response to methylphenidate, a drug that elevates extracellular dopamine (DA), is reduced in marijuana abusers, who also have higher levels of negative emotionality and addiction severity. These findings suggest that the reduced brain DA response to methylphenidate in marijuana abusers might contribute to their addictive behaviors and negative emotionality.

Language is the most complex behavior we know of. How the human brain processes language is a central question in cognitive neuroscience. We show that the most powerful artificial neural network models for language processing, when trained on these same datasets, predict brain activity and behavior in this domain. This suggests that the brain and the most powerful artificial neural networks share fundamental computational principles.

Deep learning (DL) has been a very successful paradigm in machine learning, but it has been criticized for its instability. We show that this instability is due to the fact that the algorithms used to train DL models are not stable. We introduce a new class of algorithms that are stable and prove that they can solve a wide range of inverse problems. Our results have implications for the design of stable DL models and the development of new algorithms for scientific computing.

The COVID-19 pandemic has led to a renewed interest in the psychology of exponential growth. In the 1970s, a classic experiment showed that people are unable to understand exponential growth. This study is often cited as evidence that people are unable to understand exponential growth. However, the study’s design flaws were not recognized at the time and have only recently been identified. This is a unique case study of researchers falling prey to just the cognitive bias they set out to study.

Leprosy is a disease that has been with us for thousands of years. It is caused by two distinct bacteria, Mycobacterium leprae, which causes the nerve-damaging disease leprosy, and Mycobacterium lepromatosis, which causes a nonprogressive, nonparalytic form of leprosy. We sequenced the genome of M. lepromatosis and found that it is very similar to that of M. leprae, despite the fact that they are separated by millions of years of evolution. This suggests that the two bacteria have retained many of the same genes, and that the genes that have been lost are not essential for survival. This may be important for understanding the evolution of the disease. (PsycINFO Database Record

Entanglement and entropy are two of the most important concepts in quantum mechanics. They are also the key ingredients for the description of the thermodynamic limit. However, the dynamics of these quantities is not trivial in the presence of interactions. In this paper, we show that the dynamics of entanglement in interacting systems can be understood in terms of quasiparticles, which are the elementary excitations of the system.

The COVID-19 pandemic has caused more than 200,000 deaths in the United States alone. The only vaccine currently available for use in the United States is the one developed by Pfizer and BioNTech, which requires two doses, each administered 21 days apart. We describe a vaccine that is currently in clinical development and is based on a live attenuated SARS-CoV-2 virus. This vaccine has the potential to be manufactured at large scale, is highly protective, and can be administered in a single dose.

Plague, caused by the bacterium Yersinia pestis, is one of the most devastating diseases in human history. Today, most human plague cases are caused by inhalation of infectious droplets, but the Second Pandemic (14–19th centuries) is characterized by recurrent epidemics caused by spillover of infected fleas from rodent epizootics. Here, we show that a model for plague transmission by a human ectoparasite vector fits mortality curves from nine outbreaks in Europe better than models for pneumonic or rodent transmission. Our results support that human ectoparasites were primary vectors for plague during the Second Pandemic, including the Black Death (1346–1353), ultimately challenging the assumption that plague in Europe was predominantly spread by rats. This work has implications for understanding the history of plague and the development of control measures.

The evolution of brain size has been a major focus of neuroscience and a key topic in the history of science. However, the evolution of brain information-processing capacity, which is the ultimate goal of neuroscience, has been less studied. We show that the evolution of brain information-processing capacity is not only different from that of brain size but also very different from that of body size.

TRAP1 is a mitochondrial protein that is broadly considered to be an anticancer target. However, the function of TRAP1 in mitochondria is more complex than previously appreciated. We have shown that TRAP1 regulates a metabolic switch between oxidative phosphorylation and aerobic glycolysis in immortalized mouse fibroblasts and in human tumor cells. TRAP1-deficiency promotes an increase in mitochondrial respiration and fatty acid oxidation, and in cellular accumulation of tricarboxylic acid cycle intermediates, ATP and reactive oxygen species. At the same time, glucose metabolism is suppressed. TRAP1-deficient cells also display strikingly enhanced invasiveness. TRAP1 interaction with and regulation of mitochondrial c-Src provide a mechanistic basis for these phenotypes. Taken together with the observation that TRAP1 expression is inversely correlated with tumor grade in several cancers, these data suggest that, in some settings, this mitochondrial molecular chaperone may act as a tumor suppressor. Future studies will be required to determine the extent to which TRAP1 is a tumor suppressor in vivo. (PsycINFO Database Record

Actin depolymerizing factor (ADF) is a protein that is involved in the disassembly of actin filaments. It does so by binding to the filament and causing it to sever. However, how it does so is not fully understood. Here, we show that ADF binds to the filament in a way that is sensitive to the mechanical state of the filament. We show that the mechanical state of the filament can enhance or inhibit ADF binding, depending on the mechanical state of the filament. We propose that this mechanochemical mechanism is critical to boost ADF’s ability to sever highly connected filament networks in cells. We believe that our work will help to elucidate the mechanism of ADF/cofilin action and will provide a foundation for the development of new strategies for the treatment of actin-based diseases.

Fructose, a common sweetener found in many foods and beverages, is a weaker appetite suppressant than glucose, a common sweetener found in many other foods and beverages. We show that the ingestion of fructose relative to glucose results in greater activation of brain regions involved in attention and reward processing and may promote feeding behavior. These findings have implications for understanding the role of fructose in the development of obesity and for the design of interventions to reduce the consumption of foods that are high in calories but low in nutrients. (PsycINFO Database Record

Madagascar is a unique island, both in terms of its biodiversity and its human history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across the island, and we found that the Malagasy population is a mixture of Bantu and Austronesian populations, with a limited contribution from Europe and the Middle East. We also found that the settlement of Madagascar happened in a sex-biased way, with a higher probability of settlement from Africa than from Asia. Finally, we found that the genetic structure of the population is already detectable after a few centuries, suggesting that the island is a good laboratory to study the effects of geography and time on the human genome. We show that people’s emotions can be transferred to others via social networks. This is a surprising result, because it suggests that people do not need to interact in person to be influenced by others’ emotions. This work also suggests that, in contrast to prevailing assumptions, in-person interaction and nonverbal cues are not strictly necessary for emotional contagion, and that the observation of others’ positive experiences constitutes a positive experience for people.

Messenger RNAs (mRNAs) are the primary source of protein in all cells. However, the ribosome can also read and decode the sequence of the mRNA coding regions to produce a variety of nonprotein-coding RNAs. One of the most common modifications in coding regions is pseudouridine (Ψ), which can have a variety of effects on the protein encoded by the mRNA. We show that the presence of Ψ in the mRNA can alter the rate of protein synthesis and the rate of near-cognate amino acid incorporation. Our results suggest that the presence of Ψ in the mRNA can have a modest effect on the decoding of the mRNA sequence. This study provides a foundation for understanding the impact of mRNA modifications on protein synthesis. (Show more)

We show that the feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities is associated with a wide range of positive outcomes, including better health, stronger social relationships, and a healthier lifestyle. This is the first study to our knowledge to show that the feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities is associated with a wide range of positive outcomes, including better health, stronger social relationships, and a healthier lifestyle.

The evolution of body size in mammals is one of the most studied topics in biology. We show that the evolution of an aquatic lifestyle is driving three of the four extant aquatic mammal clades toward a size attractor at ∼500 kg. This size attractor is consistent with the energetic constraints of the aquatic medium.

The common cold is the most common disease worldwide, and rhinovirus is the most common cause of the common cold. The cool temperature of the nasal cavity is the preferred temperature for rhinovirus replication. We show that the mouse-adapted rhinovirus replicates more efficiently at the cool temperature of the nasal cavity than at core body temperature. We also show that the cool temperature leads to a less efficient antiviral defense response of infected cells. These findings have implications for the development of vaccines and antiviral therapies for the common cold. (Show more)

Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a major cause of infections in the human body and the environment. It is a master of surface attachment and biofilm formation, which are essential for its survival and pathogenicity. Here we show that the opportunistic pathogen can sense the mechanical activity of its pili, which are used for surface attachment and twitching motility. This mechanosensory system is mediated by the Chp chemosensory system, which regulates the production of the second messenger cAMP and the expression of hundreds of genes, including key virulence factors. Our results thus demonstrate that type IV pili are not only used for surface attachment, but also as a sensor that regulates the expression of virulence factors. This mechanochemical model for surface sensing may be a general mechanism for bacteria to sense their environment. (Show more)

The use of pesticides in agriculture has increased dramatically over the last decades. However, the impact of pesticides on the quality of surface water is still poorly understood. We show that the presence of pesticides in surface water is very high, and that the quality of water resources is at a substantial risk. Our results suggest that the use of pesticides in agriculture should be reduced, and that the application of pesticides should be more carefully timed to avoid the risk of pesticide contamination of surface water.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a profound impact on the human population, and the animal world has not been immune. In this study, we report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in white-tailed deer, which is of great concern because of the potential for the virus to persist in the wild animal population. We also show that the virus can be transmitted between deer, and that the virus has likely been circulating in deer for some time. These findings have important implications for the long-term persistence of the pandemic.

The world is moving toward a more sustainable energy future. This paper examines the proliferation of large dams in developing countries and the importance of incorporating climate change into considerations of whether to build a dam along with some of the governance and compensation challenges. We also examine the overestimation of benefits and underestimation of costs along with changes that are needed to address the legitimate social and environmental concerns of people living in areas where dams are planned. Finally, we propose innovative solutions that can move hydropower toward sustainable practices together with solar, wind, and other renewable sources.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia, and the amyloid-β (Aβ) protein is the primary pathological hallmark of the disease. However, the role of Aβ in the initiation and progression of AD is still unclear. Here, we show that neurons, which are the primary cell type responsible for Aβ production, are also the major source of the inflammatory response in AD.

The chicken is today one of the most widespread domesticated species, but its economic exploitation is a relatively recent phenomenon. We show that the earliest evidence for economic exploitation of chickens comes from the Hellenistic site of Maresha, Israel. We argue that the gradual acclimatization of chickens in the Southern Levant and its gradual integration into the local economy, the latter fully accomplished in the Hellenistic period, was a crucial step in the adoption of this species in European husbandry some 100 y later.

We have developed a method that allows the study of the folding of a protein at high structural resolution. We have used this method to study the folding of the maltose binding protein, a large protein that is known to fold through distinct native-like intermediates in distinct pathways. We find that the intermediates are not transient, but persist through the rest of the folding process. We also find that the intermediates are among the least protected parts of the protein. These results add a large protein to the list of proteins known to fold through distinct native-like intermediates in distinct pathways. This is the first time that such intermediates have been observed in a large protein. The results have implications for the design of proteins with improved folding properties. (Show more)

Dinucleoside tetraphosphates, which are often described as alarmones because their cellular concentration increases in response to stress, have recently been shown to function in bacteria as precursors to nucleoside tetraphosphate (Np4) RNA caps. In this study, we show that the RNA pyrophosphohydrolase RppH, which is inactivated by the very conditions of disulfide stress that enable Np4-capped RNAs to accumulate to high levels, is the predominant decapping enzyme in Escherichia coli cells experiencing such stress. Unexpectedly, this enzyme recognizes Np4-capped 5′ ends by a mechanism distinct from the one it uses to recognize other 5′ termini, resulting in a one-nucleotide shift in substrate specificity. The unconventional manner in which RppH recognizes Np4-capped 5′ ends and its differential impact on the rates at which such termini are deprotected as a prelude to RNA degradation could have major consequences for reprogramming gene expression during disulfide stress. (Read more)

Sepsis is a life-threatening condition that is associated with a high mortality rate. The mechanisms involved in the development of immunosuppression during sepsis are not fully understood. We hypothesized that increasing arginine availability would restore T cell function and decrease immunosuppression. We found that citrulline, an amino acid that is derived from arginine, was more efficient than arginine in increasing arginine plasma levels and restoring T cell mitochondrial function and proliferation while reducing immunosuppression. Because there is no specific therapeutic strategy to restore immune function after sepsis, we believe that our study provides evidence for developing citrulline-based clinical studies in sepsis. This study also provides evidence for the development of new strategies to treat other conditions in which arginine deprivation is involved. (PsycINFO Database Record

The biomass of all living organisms is a fundamental quantity for understanding the structure and dynamics of the biosphere. However, a global, quantitative view of how the biomass of different taxa compare with one another is still lacking. Here, we assemble the overall biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a census of the ≈550 Gt C of biomass distributed among all of the kingdoms of life. We show that the biomass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined, and that the global marine biomass pyramid contains more consumers than producers. Our analysis highlights the importance of the human impact on the global biomass of prominent taxa, including mammals, fish, and plants. Our results provide a global view of the biomass composition of the biosphere and can be used to understand the structure and dynamics of the biosphere. View Full-Text

Self-organized criticality (SOC) is a fascinating phenomenon in nature and physics, where systems evolve in a self-sustaining manner. In this paper, we report on our discovery of a tropical model with SOC behavior. Our model is continuous, in contrast to all known models of SOC, and is a certain scaling limit of the sandpile model, the first and archetypical model of SOC. We describe how our model is related to pattern formation and proportional growth phenomena and discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models in several contexts. Our aim in this context is to present an idealized tropical toy model, requiring further investigation.

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal conductivity. It is a promising material for optoelectronics, photonics, and quantum applications. However, diamond is also a material with a high risk of phonon instability under large mechanical strain. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized reversibly under strain, and that the bandgap can be tuned from indirect to direct. We also show that the instability of diamond under large strain can be used to control the phase transition to graphite. These findings offer opportunities for tailoring properties of diamond via strain engineering for electronic, photonic, and quantum applications. View Full-Text
This paper is about the discovery of a new class of antifungal peptides that are effective against plant fungal pathogens.

The male–female reproductive interface is a critical site of interaction between sperm and the female reproductive tract. In this study, we show that the proteome of Drosophila sperm undergoes substantial changes after being transferred to the female reproductive tract. We also show that the female reproductive tract contributes to the proteome of sperm, and that these changes are associated with energy metabolism. Our research provides a comprehensive characterization of sperm proteome dynamics and expands our understanding of the critical process of sperm–FRT interactions. (Show more)

Von Willebrand factor (VWF) is a large protein that binds to platelets, where it is essential for stopping bleeding. Mutations in VWF cause the common bleeding disorder, von Willebrand disease (VWD). We show that the A1 domain in VWF binds to the platelet receptor glycoprotein Ibα (GPIbα) and that the binding is regulated by flow. We also show that force can switch the A1 domain to a second state with faster binding, which is important for platelet activation. This mechanism explains the pathophysiology of VWD, which is caused by mutations in the A1 domain.

The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem that is the focus of intense study. The viral component of the microbiome has been a more challenging target than the bacteriome, in part because of the lack of a comprehensive database for human-associated viruses. We present a database that contains over 45,000 unique virus taxa, with historically high per-genome completeness. We use this database to identify over 2,200 virus–disease associations, and to show that the virome is a significant contributor to human health. This database will be useful to the microbiome research community for many years to come.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is a complex process that is difficult to be well represented in current climate models. Progress on understanding ACI processes is hampered by inadequate observational capability. Here, we introduce a new instrument, the dual-field-of-view high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL), to investigate the interactions between aerosol loading and water cloud microphysical properties. The HSRL is able to measure aerosol and water cloud properties simultaneously, which is not possible with current remote-sensing techniques. A case study over Beijing highlights the scientific potential of the HSRL to become a significant contributor to the ACI investigations. The observations obtained from the HSRL constitute substantial and significant additions to understanding ACI process. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI. View Full-Text

The temperature of Earth’s surface has been a subject of intense debate for more than a century. The temperature of the early Earth is of particular interest because it is believed to have played a critical role in the origin and evolution of life. We present a method for determining the temperature of the early Earth based on the thermostability of enzymes reconstructed from ancient bacteria and archaea.

Ion channels are the main regulators of ion flow. They open and close their pore gates to control ion flow. Ion channels commonly possess two pore gates, one for fast channel activation/deactivation and the other for slow C-type inactivation/recovery. We found that the large-conductance calcium-activated potassium (BK) channel lacks a classic intracellular bundle-crossing activation gate and normally show no C-type inactivation. We induced C-type inactivation in BK channels and studied the relationship between activation/deactivation and C-type inactivation/recovery. We observed prominent slow C-type inactivation/recovery in BK channels by an extreme low concentration of extracellular K+ together with a Y294E/K/Q/S or Y279F mutation whose equivalent in Shaker channels (T449E/K/D/Q/S or W434F) caused a greatly accelerated rate of C-inactivation or constitutive C-inactivation. C-type inactivation in most K+ channels occurs upon sustained membrane depolarization or channel opening and then recovers during hyperpolarized membrane potentials or channel closure. Malaria is one of the most devastating diseases in the world, with 207 million cases and 445,000 deaths in 2017. The parasite, Plasmodium, uses a number of mechanisms to invade the red blood cell, the target of the disease. Here, we show that the malaria parasite alters the biophysical properties of the red blood cell, which may help to facilitate invasion.

However, diamond is also a material with a high risk of phonon instability under large mechanical strain. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized reversibly under strain, and that the bandgap can be tuned from indirect to direct. We also show that the instability of diamond under large strain can be used to control the phase transition to graphite. Influenza virus is a major cause of respiratory disease, and seasonal outbreaks correlate with decreases in ambient humidity. However, the impact of humidity on host response to influenza virus infection and disease outcome remains unclear. Here, we show that housing mice in low relative humidity makes them more susceptible to severe disease following respiratory challenge with influenza A virus. We find that inhalation of dry air impairs mucociliary clearance, innate antiviral defense, and tissue repair. Moreover, disease exacerbated by low humidity was ameliorated in caspase-1/11–deficient mice, independent of viral burden. Single-cell RNA sequencing revealed that induction of IFN-stimulated genes in response to viral infection was diminished in multiple cell types in the lung of mice housed in low humidity condition. These results indicate that exposure to dry air impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. Our findings provide insights into the mechanisms of dry air-induced disease severity and may lead to the development of strategies to reduce the impact of influenza virus infection in dry environments. The brain is thought to process language in a hierarchical fashion, with the most complex syntactic structures built from simpler ones. However, the neurophysiological evidence for this view is limited. Here, we show that the brain’s activity increases with each successive word in a sentence but decreases when words are merged into phrases. This pattern of activity is consistent with a merge operation that applies equally to linguistic objects of arbitrary complexity. Our results suggest that the brain builds syntactic structures by combining smaller units into larger ones. They also provide initial evidence for a neural implementation of a left-corner parser of the incoming language stream. Our findings may help to explain the origins of human language and the brain’s ability to process it. (PsycINFO Database Record

Axin is a key component of the Wnt signaling pathway, which is involved in a wide range of biological processes. In this study, we show that the two forms of Axin in vertebrates are not only similar at the protein level but also at the level of gene regulation. We demonstrate that the two forms of Axin are regulated differently, which may be used to control the activity of the two forms of Axin in different tissues.
This paper is about the brain circuits that promote overeating. It is about the brain circuits that may contribute to obesity.

Symbiotic associations between plants and bacteria are the most important biological nitrogen fixers in nature. However, in agriculture, the vast majority of nitrogen is supplied by synthetic sources, which are nonrenewable and unsustainable. We have developed a system that allows the control of the nitrogen-fixing symbiosis between plants and bacteria, and we have shown that it is possible to control the activity of the nitrogenase enzyme, which fixes the nitrogen, only when the plant is in contact with the bacteria. This work represents a key milestone toward the development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis in which the bacteria fix nitrogen only when in contact with the desired host plant and are prevented from interaction with nontarget plant species. This work could lead to a sustainable source of nitrogen for agriculture. (Show more)

We study the effects of a community-based monitoring program in the Peruvian Amazon that facilitated transfer of early deforestation alerts from the Global Forest Watch network to indigenous communities and trained and incentivized community members to patrol forests in response to those alerts. We find that the program reduced tree cover loss, but the estimated effects from the experiment are imprecise. Data from monitoring records and community surveys provide evidence about how the program may affect forest outcomes. Community members perceived that the program’s monitors were new authorities with influence over forest management and that the monitors’ incentivized patrols were substitutes for traditional, unincentivized citizen patrols that suffer from free riding and inhibit timely community detection of and responses to deforestation. Should our findings be replicated elsewhere, they imply that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols that combine remote-sensed early deforestation alerts with training and incentives for monitors could contribute to sustainable forest management.

Hearing is a fundamental sense of many animals, including all mammals, birds, some reptiles, amphibians, fish, and arthropods. The auditory organs of these animals are extremely diverse in anatomy after hundreds of millions of years of evolution, yet they are all made up of cellular tissue and are morphologically part of the bodies of animals. Here, we show that hearing in the orb-weaving spider Larinioides sclopetarius is not constrained by the organism’s body but is extended through outsourcing hearing to its extended phenotype, the proteinaceous, self-manufactured orb web. We find that the wispy, wheel-shaped orb web acts as a hyperacute acoustic antenna to capture the sound-induced air particle movements that approach the maximum physical efficiency better than the acoustic responsivity of all previously known eardrums. By sensing the motion of web threads, the spider remotely detects and localizes the source of an incoming airborne acoustic wave, such as those emitted by approaching prey or predators. By outsourcing its acoustic sensors to its web, the spider is released from body size constraints and permits the araneid spider to increase its sound-sensitive surface area enormously, up to 10,00

We show that a rapid phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources are needed to save millions of lives, restore aerosol-perturbed rainfall patterns, and limit global warming to 2 °C.

COVID-19 is a global pandemic that has caused millions of deaths. The development of vaccines is a critical response to the pandemic, and many are in development. Here we report the design and characterization of a recombinant protein subunit vaccine candidate that is well-suited for large-scale production and has the potential to be a low-cost vaccine for the global population.

We show that the zebrafish homolog of human anaplastic lymphoma kinase (ALK) is a ligand for a family of secreted proteins. This discovery has important implications for our understanding of the role of ALK in the development of neural crest-derived tissues, as well as in the development of cancer.

Plague is one of the most devastating diseases in human history, and the pathogen that causes it has been a constant threat to humanity for millennia. We present the first ancient Yersinia pestis genomes from the Late Neolithic and Early Bronze Age period, which is a critical time in the development of the disease. Our results show that the disease underwent a series of evolutionary steps before it became the plague we know today, and that it spread rapidly across Eurasia during this period. These data provide a unique window into the formative years of plague, and may have important implications for understanding the spread of the disease throughout human history. (Less)

This work examined the role of the culturally endorsed form of masculinity—hegemonic masculinity (HM)—in men’s and women’s support for Donald Trump in the 2016 American presidential election and Joe Biden in the 2020 election. Consistent with our theoretical backdrop, HM predicted voting for and evaluations of Trump, over and above political party affiliation, gender, race, and education. These effects held when controlling for respondents’ trust in the government, in contrast to a populist explanation of support for Trump. In addition, HM was associated with less trust in the government, more sexism, more racism, and more xenophobia but continued to predict unique variance in evaluations of Trump when controlling for each of these factors. The findings highlight the importance of psychological examinations of masculinity as a cultural ideology to understand how men’s and women’s endorsement of HM legitimizes patriarchal dominance and reinforces gender, race, and class-based hierarchies. The findings have implications for understanding the political and social consequences of masculinity in the United States.

Soil organic carbon (SOC) sequestration in agricultural systems is a critical strategy for mitigating climate change. However, the management of annual cropping systems on grassland-derived Mollisols has led to massive C losses to the atmosphere. We show that soil health management practices that reduce soil disturbance, diversify crop rotations, and integrate livestock can increase SOC storage and the distribution of SOC between particulate and mineral-associated pools. These results highlight the potential of well-managed grasslands to sequester SOC and highlight the importance of including perennial pastures in climate-smart agricultural systems. Our findings have implications for the global effort to mitigate climate change and the need to restore and protect natural ecosystems. (Less)

The death toll and economic loss resulting from the severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) pandemic are stark reminders that we are vulnerable to zoonotic viral threats. We used expert opinion and scientific evidence to identify host, viral, and environmental risk factors contributing to zoonotic virus spillover and spread in humans. We then developed a risk ranking framework and interactive web tool, SpillOver, that estimates a risk score for wildlife-origin viruses, creating a comparative risk assessment of viruses with uncharacterized zoonotic spillover potential alongside those already known to be zoonotic. Using data from virus discovery projects and public records of virus detections around the world, we ranked the spillover potential of 887 wildlife viruses. Validating the risk assessment, the top 12 were known zoonotic viruses. The SpillOver platform can be used by policy makers and health scientists to inform research and public health interventions for prevention and rapid control of disease outbreaks. SpillOver is a living, interactive database that can be refined over time to continue to improve the quality and public availability of information on viral threats to human health.

Nectar is the main reward that plants offer to pollinators for visitation. One of the main rewards plants offer to pollinators for visitation is nectar. Nesocodon mauritianus (Campanulaceae) produces a blood-red nectar that has been proposed to serve as a visual attractant for pollinator visitation. We show that the nectar’s red color is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid termed nesocodin. We identify three enzymes that are necessary or sufficient for the production of the red pigment, and we show that the same enzymes are involved in the production of the yellow nectar. We also identify nesocodin in the red nectar of the hummingbird-visited Jaltomata herrerae, suggesting that this type of adaptation is convergent. This work identifies a convergently evolved trait in two vertebrate-pollinated species, suggesting that the red pigment is selectively favored and that only a limited number of compounds are likely to underlie this type of adaptation. We present the first genome-wide data from the Early Medieval period in Europe. We show that the genetic ancestry of men is mostly consistent with modern northern and central Europeans, but that the genetic ancestries of women are very heterogeneous, including signals of genetic ancestry ranging from western Europe to East Asia. We also show that many alleles associated with recent positive selection were already at modern-like frequencies in European populations ∼1,500 years ago. This example of female-biased migration indicates that complex demographic processes during the Early Medieval period may have contributed in an unexpected way to shape the modern European genetic landscape.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a zoonotic pathogen that causes ∼36% fatality in infected patients. Believed to have originated from bats, MERS-CoV is genetically related to bat coronaviruses HKU4 and HKU5. To understand how HKU4 and HKU5 transmit to humans, we investigated the receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins of HKU4 and HKU5. We found that dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP4), the receptor for MERS-CoV, is also the receptor for HKU4, but not HKU5. Despite sharing a common receptor, MERS-CoV and HKU4 spikes demonstrated functional differences. These results suggest that MERS-CoV, but not HKU4, has adapted to use human cells for cross-species transmission. They also suggest that DPP4-recognizing bat coronaviruses threaten human health because of their spikes’ capability to adapt to human cells. (PsycINFO Database Record

This study is a proof of concept for the use of metagenomic next-generation sequencing (mNGS) for the rapid detection of pathogens in resource-scarce settings. We show that mNGS can be used to identify a variety of vector-borne, zoonotic, and emerging pathogens in a periurban population in Cambodia. We demonstrate that mNGS can be used to identify the breadth of endemic, zoonotic, or emerging pathogens and deployment of rapid public health response. This study highlights the importance of ongoing pathogen surveillance in resource-scarce settings to better identify the breadth of endemic, zoonotic, or emerging pathogens and deployment of rapid public health response.

The human genome is synthesized in a complex process called DNA replication. This process is essential for the survival of all organisms and is carried out by a complex set of proteins. One of the proteins involved in this process is proliferating cell nuclear antigen (PCNA), which is essential for the synthesis of the lagging strand. In this study, we have determined the stability of the PCNA-pol δ holoenzyme, which is essential for the synthesis of the lagging strand. We have found that the stability of the holoenzyme is low, which is important for the synthesis of the lagging strand. The origin of life is one of the most important problems in biology. In this paper, we describe the development of a system that can synthesize all of the molecules necessary for the replication and expression of genetic information in the absence of proteins.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We use this method to show that three factors predict neighborhood improvement: the density of college-educated adults, the initial appearance of the neighborhood, and the proximity of the neighborhood to other attractive neighborhoods. These results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our results also provide a new way to measure the success of urban revitalization efforts.

The treatment of COVID-19 is still in the early stage, and the treatment effect is still not satisfactory. In this study, we found that tocilizumab, which is effective in the treatment of rheumatoid arthritis, can reduce the mortality of severe and critical COVID-19 patients, and can reduce the risk of lung lesions and the need for oxygen therapy.

Copper is an essential micronutrient, but at high concentrations it is toxic. The ability of fungi to sense and respond to copper is well established, but the role of the xanthocillin biosynthetic gene cluster in copper homeostasis and interactions with competing microbes is not. We demonstrate that the xanthocillin BGC is present in several filamentous fungi, and that the isocyanide products of the BGC bind copper and have antimicrobial properties. These results suggest that the xanthocillin BGC is involved in the sensing and response of fungi to copper, and may be involved in interactions with competing microbes. This is the first demonstration of a role for a fungal natural product in copper homeostasis and mediation of interactions with competing microbes. (Show more)

The formation of tridymite, a low-pressure, high-temperature polymorph of SiO2, is a well-known process in the terrestrial volcanic environment. The detection of tridymite in a sedimentary rock at Gale crater, Mars, is a significant discovery. The presence of tridymite in a sedimentary rock at this location is consistent with the hypothesis that the sedimentary rocks at the base of the sedimentary sequence at the base of the crater are the result of a volcanic event.

Frost is a major environmental stressor that affects the performance of plants and animals across the world’s temperate and boreal zones. Despite their ecological and economic impact, the geographic distribution and evolutionary impact of frost events are poorly understood. We show that the geographic distribution of frost events is linked to the leaf-out strategy of trees, and that the resistance strategies of trees are linked to the rate of change in frost events. Our findings reveal region-specific changes in the spring-frost risk that can inform decision-making in land management, forestry, agriculture, and insurance policy.

Th17 cells are central to the pathogenesis of certain types of inflammatory bowel disease, but the mechanisms by which they contribute to disease are not well understood. We show that the development of Th17 cells is contingent on the expression of both Stat4 and T-bet, but not the IL-12 or IFN-γ receptors. Moreover, we show that Th17 cells can provide “help” for the development of classic Th1 cells. These results indicate that Th17 cells are potent mediators of colitis pathogenesis by dual mechanisms: by directly transitioning to Th1-like cells and by supporting the development of classic Th1 cells. Our findings have important implications for the development of therapies for inflammatory bowel disease. (PsycINFO Database Record

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a fatal neurodegenerative disease with no cure. We have developed a method to convert human fibroblasts into induced astrocytes, which can be used to study the disease and screen for potential therapies.

This study provides a unique example of a human pathogen using an arthropod antibacterial protein to alter the gut microbiota of its vector. The results of this study have important implications for the control of vector-borne diseases, as well as for the development of new antibacterial agents.

The evolution of the avian tail is one of the most important transitions in the history of birds. However, the study of the early history of the tail is limited by the lack of known fossils. Here, we describe a basal member of the group of birds with a short tail, the pygostylians, and provide new insights into the evolution of the avian tail.
We show that the stratosphere is a major contributor to the climate system, and that it is important to understand the role of the stratosphere in climate.

Vertebrates have a variety of colors, from red to blue, and the color of an animal can be used to assess its health, identity, and even its species. In this study, we show that the color of anurans (frogs and toads) has evolved multiple times during their evolutionary history, and that the color of the animals is determined by the presence of a specific class of proteins that bind biliverdin, a pigment that is the main constituent of the heme of hemoglobin. Our results provide a molecular and functional explanation for the evolution of the color of anurans, and introduce a function for a member of the serpin superfamily, the largest and most ubiquitous group of protease inhibitors. We also show that the serpin family has been functionally diversified in vertebrates. This study provides a unique example of the evolution of color and color-based communication in vertebrates. (Show more)

Breast cancer is the most common malignancy in women worldwide. The development of the disease is influenced by a number of factors, including the hypoxic environment. In this study, we show that the hypoxic microenvironment induces the expression of ALKBH5, an m6A demethylase, which in turn increases the expression of NANOG, a gene that encodes a pluripotency factor. NANOG expression is regulated by the hypoxia-inducible factor (HIF) pathway, and the NANOG 3′-untranslated region (3′-UTR) contains a methylated m6A residue that is demethylated by ALKBH5. ALKBH5 expression increases the percentage of breast cancer cells that are cancer stem cell (CSC)-like, which may be a mechanism by which hypoxia promotes the development of CSCs. Our findings may lead to the development of new therapies for breast cancer. (Read more)

The Bible is one of the most widely read books in the world. The first pocket Bibles were made in the 13th century, and the source of the parchment used to make them has been a long-standing controversy. Here, we report a simple and objective method for identifying the animal origin of parchment. We found no evidence for the use of unexpected animals, such as rabbits, but did identify the use of more than one mammal species in a single manuscript, consistent with the local availability of hides. These results suggest that ultrafine vellum does not necessarily derive from the use of abortive or newborn animals with ultrathin hides, but could equally well reflect a production process that allowed the skins of maturing animals of several species to be rendered into vellum of equal quality and fineness.

The end-Permian mass extinction was the most severe extinction event in the last 542 My. We present a precise age model for the extinction based on U-Pb dates from volcanic ash beds. The extinction occurred between 251.941 ± 0.037 and 251.880 ± 0.031 Mya, an interval of 60 ± 48 ka. Onset of a major reorganization of the carbon cycle immediately precedes the initiation of extinction and is punctuated by a sharp (3‰), short-lived negative spike in the isotopic composition of carbonate carbon. Carbon cycle volatility persists for ∼500 ka before a return to near preextinction values. Decamillenial to millennial level resolution of the mass extinction and its aftermath will permit a refined evaluation of the relative roles of rate-dependent processes contributing to the extinction. This will allow insight into postextinction ecosystem expansion, and establish an accurate time point for evaluating the plausibility of trigger and kill mechanisms. (PsycINFO Database Record

Inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) is a group of chronic inflammatory diseases of the gastrointestinal tract, which is caused by the dysregulation of the immune system. IBD is a major health problem, and the current treatment is limited. In this study, we found that retinoic acid-related orphan receptor α (RORα) is crucial for maintaining intestinal homeostasis by attenuating nuclear factor κB (NF-κB) transcriptional activity. We also found that RORα/HDAC3-mediated attenuation of NF-κB signaling controls the balance of inflammatory responses. Our study provides a potential therapeutic target for IBD. This study also provides a new perspective for the treatment of IBD. (Show more)

We have determined the structure of the SARS-CoV-2 spike protein in complex with the receptor ACE2. We find that the D614G mutation in the spike protein has resulted in a more open conformation of the receptor-binding domain. This may facilitate binding to the receptor and the subsequent structural rearrangements required for viral membrane fusion. Our results suggest that the D614G mutation may have increased the transmissibility of the virus.

We consider repeated games with tail-measurable payoffs, i.e., when the payoffs depend only on what happens in the long run. We show that every such game admits an ε-equilibrium, for every ε>0, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite and the action sets are finite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs.

COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States. We estimate that the pandemic has resulted in a 1.13-y reduction in life expectancy at birth and a 0.87-y reduction at age 65 y for the total US population, and a 2.10-y and 3.05-y reduction for Black and Latino Americans, respectively. These projections imply an increase of nearly 40% in the Black−White life expectancy gap, from 3.6 y to over 5 y, thereby eliminating progress made in reducing this differential since 2006. Latinos, who have consistently experienced lower mortality than Whites, would see their more than 3-y survival advantage reduced to less than 1 y. These findings highlight the need for urgent action to address the structural inequalities that have led to the disproportionate burden of COVID-19 in the United States. (PsycINFO Database Record

The study of the chemical properties of matter under pressure is of fundamental importance for the understanding of the physical properties of matter and the evolution of the chemical world. Here, we show that the chemical properties of matter change under pressure, and we provide a predictive model for the behavior of these properties.

Fire is a key natural process in terrestrial ecosystems, but its effects on climate are poorly understood. We show that changes in fire activity, driven by climate, demography, and human activity, can have a large impact on the global carbon cycle. We find that, although uncertainty in projected fire effects is large, changes in human demography tend to suppress global fire activity, keeping more carbon within terrestrial ecosystems and attenuating warming. Our results highlight the importance of fire in moderating the climate system and the need to consider the role of human activity in shaping the future of fire regimes.

This study provides a new perspective on the role of host-derived nutrients in the regulation of the activities of symbionts. We show that the provision of a single glycan, chitin, by the host to its symbiont, Vibrio fischeri, is critical for the maintenance of a stable symbiosis. This glycan is consumed by the symbiont, which uses it to modify the pH of the crypts, which in turn enhances the activity of the symbiont.
