We show that the provision of a single glycan, chitin, by the host to its symbiont, Vibrio fischeri, is critical for the maintenance of a stable symbiosis. This glycan is consumed by the symbiont, which uses it to modify the pH of the crypts, which in turn enhances the activity of the symbiont. This study provides a new perspective on the role of host-derived nutrients in the regulation of the activities of symbionts. (PsycINFO Database Record

Text data are ubiquitous, and the need for methods to identify latent patterns is growing. We introduce a method to identify topics in text data and represent documents as topic sequences. We use this method to identify latent topics in the narratives of the US National Violent Death Reporting System, a database of violent death incidents. We find that the narratives contain topics that are not captured by the structured variables of the database. We also find that the topics are gendered, and that the gendered nature of the topics is related to the gender of the victims. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model topics in text data. It can be used to identify latent patterns in many domains. We believe that it will be useful to researchers and practitioners in many fields.

The Black Death, which originated in Asia, arrived in the Mediterranean harbors of Europe in 1347 CE. This epidemic marked the start of the second plague pandemic, which lasted in Europe until the early 19th century. We show that the climate conditions in Asia, where the disease originated, were favorable for the survival of Yersinia pestis, the bacterium that causes plague, during the 14th century. This suggests that the bacterium was reintroduced into Europe via the land and sea trade routes of the ancient Silk Road system, rather than by a single introduction event. Our results provide evidence for repeated climate-driven reintroductions of the bacterium into European harbors from reservoirs in Asia, with a delay of 15 ± 1 y. We find no evidence for the existence of permanent plague reservoirs in medieval Europe. (Less)

Asteroid species are a major component of the marine food web and are important for the functioning of coastal ecosystems. However, they are also a food source for a variety of predators, including sea stars, which are themselves a food source for a variety of predators, including humans. In recent years, a disease has caused the mass mortality of asteroid species. We show that the disease is caused by a virus and that the virus is spread by sea stars. This is the first report of a virus causing mass mortality of asteroid species.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is a highly aggressive cancer with a poor prognosis. The identification of targets for therapy is therefore of great importance. We have identified IL1RAP (IL1R3) as a target for therapy of AML. We show that the antibody targeting IL1RAP is able to kill AML cells in a manner that is dependent on effector-cell–mediated killing and that this antibody is able to block the proliferation of primary AML cells. Thus, IL1RAP can be efficiently targeted with an antibody capable of both achieving antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity and blocking of IL-1 signaling as modes of action. These results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Madagascar is a unique island, both in terms of its biodiversity and its human history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across the island, and we found that the Malagasy population is a mixture of Bantu and Austronesian populations, with a limited contribution from Europe and the Middle East. We also found that the settlement of Madagascar happened in a sex-biased way, with a higher probability of settlement from Africa than from Asia. Finally, we found that the genetic structure of the Malagasy population is already detectable after a few centuries, suggesting that the island is a unique place to study the effects of geography and time on human diversity.

Bacteria have evolved small RNAs (sRNAs) to regulate numerous biological processes and stress responses. While sRNAs generally are considered to be “noncoding,” a few have been found to also encode a small protein. Here we describe one such dual-function RNA that modulates carbon utilization in Escherichia coli. The 164-nucleotide RNA was previously shown to encode a 28-amino acid protein (denoted AzuC). We discovered the membrane-associated AzuC protein interacts with aerobic glycerol-3-phosphate dehydrogenase, and increases dehydrogenase activity. We also found that the RNA base pairs with two genes, encoding enzymes involved in carbon utilization, and that the base pairing interferes with the RNA’s ability to repress the genes. These results demonstrate that the translation and base-pairing functions compete. This is an example of a dual-function RNA that has been overlooked in the past. We believe that this RNA is important for understanding the regulation of carbon utilization in bacteria.

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against such variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. We anticipate that our approach will be useful for other protein molecules, including those used in vaccines. Our work has the potential to improve the efficacy of vaccines and antibody-based therapies against SARS-CoV-2 variants.

Crop experts are the first line of defense for the US Department of Agriculture (USDA) in monitoring the health of the nation’s crops. However, the USDA Crop Progress and Condition (CPC) survey is plagued by biases and is only available for a limited time. We show that the CPC can be transformed into a continuous, probabilistic variable that is more suitable for quantitative analysis. We also show that the CPC is robust to changes in the number of surveyors and the number of crops, and that it has nation-wide validity. We demonstrate that the CPC can be used to monitor crop status and provide earlier and more precise predictions of crop yields than official USDA forecasts released midseason. Our results show that the CPC can be used to provide a more complete picture of the health of the nation’s crops, and can be used to improve the accuracy of crop yield predictions.

Language is a complex system that requires the integration of information over time. Here we propose a mechanism for memory that is based on the adaptive changes in the excitability of neurons. We show that the dynamics of these changes can support memory on timescales ranging from milliseconds to seconds. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it can bind information over time. We believe that this mechanism is a plausible substrate for the storage and integration of linguistic information in the brain.

Soil respiration is a major component of the global carbon cycle, and its response to climate change is of great interest to the scientific community and the general public. However, despite decades of research, the response of soil respiration to warming remains unclear. We synthesize the largest global dataset to date of soil respiration, moisture, and temperature measurements, totaling over 3,800 observations representing 27 temperature manipulation studies, spanning nine biomes and over 2 decades of warming. Our analysis reveals no significant differences in the temperature sensitivity of soil respiration between control and warmed plots in all biomes, with the exception of deserts and boreal forests. Thus, our data provide limited evidence of acclimation of soil respiration to experimental warming in several major biome types, contrary to the results from multiple single-site studies. Our analysis adds a unique cross-biome perspective on the temperature response of soil respiration, information critical to improving our mechanistic understanding of how soil carbon dynamics change with climatic warming. (Less)

The evolution of the plastid genome is a powerful tool for the study of the origin and evolution of life. Here, we show that the transition from autotrophy to a parasitic lifestyle leads to a relaxation of selection pressure on the plastid genome. We demonstrate that the evolutionary rates of the plastid genome are linked to the macrostructural and microstructural changes in the genome, the extent of functional reduction, and the establishment of the obligate parasitic lifestyle. Our findings suggest that the transition to obligate parasitism relaxes functional constraints on plastid genes in a stepwise manner.

The 2015–2017 Cape Town drought is a stark reminder of the risks of climate change in South Africa and globally. We show that anthropogenic climate change increased the likelihood of the 2015–2017 drought by a factor of five to six. The probability of such an event will increase from 0.7 to 25% by the year 2100 under an intermediate-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 2-4.5) and to 80% under a high-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 5-8.5). These results highlight the strong sensitivity of the drought risk in SSA to future anthropogenic emissions. This work is a call to action for the international community to reduce greenhouse gas emissions to avoid the most severe droughts in SSA. (Show more)

The discovery of quasicrystals in nature and the laboratory has revolutionized our understanding of the structure of solids. The first known example of a quasicrystal, found in a meteorite, is now known to be only a few thousand years old. This discovery has important implications for the origin of the universe and for the search for extraterrestrial life.

Photosynthesis is the most important process on Earth, converting solar energy to chemical energy. The conversion of solar energy to chemical energy is accomplished by the capture of light by chlorophyll, the formation of a chemical energy currency, and the transfer of that energy to the cell. The formation of chlorophyll, the first step in the conversion of light to chemical energy, is a highly efficient reaction, and the mechanism of its catalysis has been the subject of intense study.

Neuroinflammation is a major feature of many neurodegenerative diseases, including multiple sclerosis (MS). In this study, we found that neuroinflammation was reduced in both the early and later stages of experimental autoimmune encephalomyelitis (EAE) in microglia/macrophage-specific ASK1 knockout mice, whereas only the later-stage neuroinflammation was ameliorated in astrocyte-specific ASK1 knockout mice. We also found that ASK1 in microglia plays a major role in generating and maintaining disease, and activated astrocytes produce key inflammatory mediators, including CCL2, that further activated and recruited microglia/macrophages, in an astrocytic ASK1-dependent manner. Our findings suggest that glial ASK1 is a promising therapeutic target for reducing neuroinflammation. This study provides a better understanding of the role of ASK1 in the glial cell-mediated neuroinflammation and may lead to the development of new strategies for the treatment of neurodegenerative diseases. California is currently in the midst of a record-setting drought. We show that the probability of drought has increased in the past two decades, and that this increase is due to human activities.

Autism is a complex disorder with a multifactorial inheritance pattern. Therefore, it is difficult to identify the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms such as social deficit, repetitive behaviors, and behavioral inflexibility. In this study, we used a reversal-learning task to measure behavioral flexibility in Drosophila and determined the effects of loss-of-function mutations in multiple autism-risk gene homologs in flies. We found that mutations of five autism-risk genes with diversified molecular functions all led to a similar phenotype of behavioral inflexibility indicated by impaired reversal-learning. These reversal-learning defects resulted from the inability to forget or rather, specifically, to activate Rac1 (Ras-related C3 botulinum toxin substrate 1)-dependent forgetting. Thus, behavior-evoked activation of Rac1-dependent forgetting has a converging function for autism-risk genes. Our results provide a mechanistic understanding of the role of behavioral flexibility in autism and may facilitate the development of new therapeutic strategies. (PsycINFO Database Record

This work is the most comprehensive cross-national demonstration of negativity biases to date, but it also highlights considerable individual-level variation in responsiveness to news content. Insofar as our results make clear the pervasiveness of negativity biases on average, they help account for the tendency for audience-seeking news around the world to be predominantly negative. Insofar as our results highlight individual-level variation, however, they highlight the potential for more positive content, and suggest that there may be reason to reconsider the conventional journalistic wisdom that “if it bleeds, it leads.”

The store-operated Ca2+ (SO) sensor STIM1 and the pore-forming protein ORAI1 are key regulators of cellular Ca2+ signaling. Mutations in these proteins cause severe immune dysfunction and muscle disease. Here, we identify two gain-of-function mutations in the cytoplasmic domain of STIM1 and one in the pore-forming protein ORAI1, which cause congenital bleeding diathesis, thrombocytopenia, and tubular myopathy. These data expand our understanding of the phenotypic spectrum of dysregulated SO signaling, advance our knowledge of the molecular function of the SO sensor STIM1, and suggest new therapies aiming at attenuating store-operated Ca2+ entry in the treatment of patients with Stormorken syndrome and related pathologic conditions. (PsycINFO Database Record

In this paper we show that the spreading of protein aggregates in the brain is a key feature of several neurodegenerative diseases. We demonstrate that the spreading of aggregates is a noncell-autonomous process, and that the internalization of aggregates is a key mechanism for the spread of disease. We also show that the release of aggregates is an active process, and that this process is important for the spread of disease. These results have important implications for the development of therapeutic strategies for neurodegenerative diseases.

Bats are increasingly accepted as potential reservoirs of many viruses that cause zoonotic disease outbreaks through spillover to other animals and humans. However, our understanding of the factors that contribute to virus spillover from bats is very limited. Here, we identified and characterized an immunosuppressant protein (MTX) that is highly concentrated in the submandibular salivary gland of the bat, Myotis pilosus. This study provides deeper insight into immunologically privileged sites for microbial community residence in bats and supports the therapeutic potential of targeting MTX-LTA4H. This study also provides a deeper understanding of the role of bats in the emergence of zoonotic viruses and the potential for the development of new antiviral drugs. (PsycINFO Database Record

Cancer is a disease of the cell cycle, and the cell cycle is fueled by the one-carbon unit derived from the amino acid serine. We have developed a small-molecule inhibitor of the enzyme that converts serine to the unit, and have shown that it is a potent inhibitor of colon cancer. We have also identified a metabolic vulnerability of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma, a cancer that is notoriously resistant to treatment. Our findings provide a rationale for the use of the inhibitor in the treatment of colon cancer, and a target for the treatment of lymphoma.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a heterogeneous disease with a variety of genetic mutations in proteins that are highly aggregation-prone. These proteins, including superoxide dismutase 1 (SOD1), TDP-43, and Fused in Sarcoma (FUS), form intracellular inclusion bodies that are characteristic of different neuropathological subtypes of the disease. We show that the proteins that form inclusions of mutant SOD1, TDP-43, and FUS are not merely a subset of the native interaction partners of these three proteins, which are themselves supersaturated. Rather, the inclusion bodies in various forms of ALS result from a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. This metastable state may be a consequence of the unique cellular environment of the motor neuron, which is a highly specialized cell type that is not found in other tissues. Our results suggest that inclusion bodies in various forms of ALS result from a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons. We present a 2D photonic crystal system for interacting with cold cesium (Cs) atoms. The band structures of the 2D photonic crystals are predicted to produce unconventional atom–light interaction behaviors, including anisotropic emission, suppressed spontaneous decay, and photon-mediated atom–atom interactions controlled by the position of the atomic array relative to the photonic crystal. The device configuration also enables application of optical tweezers for controlled placement of atoms. Devices can be fabricated reliably from a 200-nm silicon nitride device layer using a lithography-based process, producing predicted optical properties in transmission and reflection measurements. These 2D photonic crystal devices can be readily deployed to experiments for many-body physics with neutral atoms and engineering of exotic quantum matter. We believe that the results presented here will be of interest to researchers in many areas, including quantum optics, atom optics, quantum simulation, and quantum information science. The origin of the flowering plants is a major question in plant evolution. The study of Montsechia, a fossil plant from the Cretaceous, has led to a new understanding of the origin of the flowering plants.

The study of ancient viruses is important for understanding the evolution of viruses and the history of human pathogens. Here we present the first ancient human parvovirus B19 (B19V) sequences, which are dated to ∼12.6 kya. We also provide evidence for the existence of a recombination event between B19V genotypes 1 and 3 that formed B19V genotype 2. These results are important for understanding the history of B19V and the evolution of this virus.
We show that the rate of sea level rise is accelerating, and that this acceleration is consistent with the IPCC’s projections of climate change.

Pain is a common and costly problem in America today. We show that, for those with less education, pain prevalence has increased with age for each successive birth cohort, and that the increase has been greater for those born after 1950. This pattern is not explained by changes in occupation or levels of obesity. If this trend continues, tomorrow’s elderly will be sicker than today’s elderly, with potentially serious implications for healthcare.
The study of enzymes is a central theme in biology, and the study of enzymes is a central theme in chemistry. The study of enzymes is a central theme in NMR crystallography.

Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is a severe disease with a high case fatality rate. There is a need for the development of effective antiviral treatments. Here, we show that remdesivir, a nucleotide analog, is effective in preventing and treating MERS-CoV infection in a nonhuman primate model. This study supports the use of remdesivir in a clinical trial of MERS-CoV infection, and may also be considered for a wider range of coronaviruses, including the currently emerging novel coronavirus 2019-nCoV.

This study provides a new perspective on the role of host-derived nutrients in the regulation of the activities of symbionts. We show that the provision of a single glycan, chitin, by the host to its symbiont, Vibrio fischeri, is critical for the maintenance of the symbiosis, and that this glycan is consumed only at night, when the symbionts are most active. This glycan-driven regulation of the activity of the symbionts may be a general mechanism for the control of the activities of symbionts in the environment.
This paper is about the importance of relationships in schools, and the power of teachers to shape them. It is also about the importance of suspending students, and the power of teachers to do so.

DNA alkylation is one of the most common DNA lesions, which can lead to a variety of diseases. However, the molecular mechanism of how DNA alkylation affects the fidelity of transcription is still unknown. In this study, we systematically investigated the impact of alkylated thymidine lesions on transcription. We found that the transcription reaction is stalled at the alkylated thymidine lesion, and the stalling is exacerbated by the proofreading activity of RNA polymerase II. We also found that the lesion can lead to multiple transcriptional bypass routes, which are controlled by different fidelity checkpoints. Finally, we identified a minor-groove–sensing motif from RNA polymerase II, which is involved in modulating the translocation of the alkylated DNA template. This work provides important mechanistic insights into the molecular mechanism of transcription stalling and mutagenesis. It is expected to provide a new direction for the development of new drugs for the treatment of diseases caused by DNA alkylation. (Show more)

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a zoonotic pathogen that causes severe respiratory disease. To cause infection, MERS-CoV must bind to cell receptors and fuse with the cell membrane. We found that the spike (S) glycoproteins, which mediate binding and fusion, are cleaved sequentially during virus production and entry into target cells. We also found that the first cleavages are required for MERS-CoV to infect human lung-derived cells, which are relevant to lung infection. These findings suggest that the first cleavages expand the virus tropism to cell types that are relevant to lung infection, and therefore may be significant determinants of MERS-CoV virulence.

This paper provides evidence that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in a cafeteria can increase the proportion of vegetarian meals purchased by 40%. This is a large effect, and it is likely that the proportion of vegetarian meals could be increased even further. The results suggest that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in catering outlets could be a simple and effective way to help people to reduce their meat consumption and to improve population health and the environment.

Cancer is a disease of the cell surface, and the surfaceome is the interface for the cell to engage the extracellular space. We have developed a method to study the surfaceome of cancer cells, and applied it to study the surfaceome of a panel of cancer cells expressing six of the most prominent oncogenes. We find that each oncogene has a different surfaceome, but that the functions of these proteins are harmonized by common biological themes including up-regulation of nutrient transporters, down-regulation of adhesion molecules, and alteration in immune modulators. These studies provide a broad systems-level view of how specific driver oncogenes remodel the surfaceome and the glycoproteome in a cell autologous fashion, and suggest possible surface targets, and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker discovery. (Show more)

In response to the COVID-19 pandemic, many scholars and policy makers are urging the United States to expand voting-by-mail programs to safeguard the electoral process. What are the effects of vote-by-mail? In this paper, we provide a comprehensive design-based analysis of the effect of universal vote-by-mail—a policy under which every voter is mailed a ballot in advance of the election—on electoral outcomes. We find that universal vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, does not appear to increase either party’s vote share, and modestly increases overall average turnout rates, in line with previous estimates. All three conclusions support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media.

The COVID-19 pandemic has caused millions of deaths worldwide. The SARS-CoV-2 virus has been shown to be able to evade the immune system, and the molecular basis for this is largely unknown. Here, we report the structure of the SARS-CoV-2 ORF8 protein, which is a key protein for the evasion of the immune system.

Cerebral edema is a potentially life-threatening illness, but knowledge of its underlying mechanisms is limited. Here we report that hypobaric hypoxia induces rat cerebral edema and neuronal apoptosis and increases the expression of corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF), CRF receptor type 1 (CRFR1), aquaporin-4 (AQP4), and endothelin-1 (ET-1) in the cortex. These effects, except for the increased expression of CRF itself, could all be blocked by pretreatment with an antagonist of the CRF receptor CRFR1. We also show that, in cultured primary astrocytes: (i) both CRFR1 and AQP4 are expressed; (ii) exogenous CRF, acting on CRFR1, triggers signaling of cAMP/PKA, intracellular Ca2+, and PKCε; and (iii) the up-regulated cAMP/PKA signaling contributes to the phosphorylation and expression of AQP4 to enhance water influx into astrocytes and produces an up-regulation of ET-1 expression. Finally, using CHO cells transfected with CRFR1+ and AQP4+, we show that transfected CRFR1+ contributes to edema via transfected AQP4+. In conclusion,

We live in an era of big data and complex statistical modeling. The tools for cherry picking—the methods that we use to find associations in the data—are now very sophisticated. We describe some recent new developments in selective inference and illustrate their use in forward stepwise regression, the lasso, and principal components analysis. We show that these methods can be used to make more efficient use of the data, to reduce the risk of overfitting, and to make more accurate predictions. We also show how these methods can be used to address the challenge of selective inference.

The development of endothelial cells (ECs) is a complex process that requires the cooperation of multiple transcription factors. Here, we demonstrate that ets variant 2 (ETV2) is a key factor for the direct conversion of human adult skin fibroblasts into functional vascular ECs. In addition, we show that ETV2 is also essential for the formation of mature vascular networks in vivo. These findings provide a new strategy for the generation of ECs and the development of vascular networks, which may be useful for the treatment of vascular disorders. (Show more)

We have identified a number of orphan receptor tyrosine kinases (RTKs) that are important in cancer and other diseases. Here, we show that the zebrafish genome contains three genes that encode ligands for two of these RTKs. We show that these ligands are important for the development of the zebrafish eye and the body. We also show that the ligands are important for the development of iridophores, a unique type of skin cell that is found on the body and the fins of the zebrafish. These experiments establish a physiological link between the ligands and the RTKs and demonstrate that the ligands are important for the development of iridophores. This work provides a foundation for future studies of the function of these ligands in other contexts.

Type 2 diabetes (T2D) is a complex disease with multiple molecular bases. In this study, we found that the stimulator of interferon genes (STING) plays a role in the regulation of insulin sensitivity and β-cell function. We also found that STING is decreased in islets of diabetic mice and patients with T2D, suggesting a possible role of STING in β-cell dysfunction. Indeed, STING deficiency in β-cells impaired glucose-stimulated insulin secretion, indicating that STING is required for normal β-cell function. These findings provide a new perspective for the treatment of T2D. (Show more)

Influenza A viruses are the leading cause of human influenza epidemics and pandemics. The genome of the influenza A virus is segmented into eight fragments, which is an evolutionary advantage but complicates the packaging of the genome into virions. We identified a direct intermolecular interaction between two viral RNA segments of an avian influenza A virus. This interaction is required for optimal viral replication and favors the copackaging of the interacting viral RNA segments. Our results indicate that viral RNA segments can promote the selective packaging of the influenza A virus genome by forming a sequence-dependent supramolecular network of interactions. The lack of conservation of these interactions might limit genetic reassortment between divergent influenza A viruses. This work provides a molecular understanding of the selective packaging mechanism of the influenza A virus. (Show more)

Atherosclerotic lesions are the result of a complex interplay between genetic and environmental factors. The focal nature of atherosclerotic lesions suggests an important role of local hemodynamic environment. In this study, we demonstrate that the activation of YAP/TAZ by disturbed flow is a critical mechanism in promoting the development of atheroprone phenotypes and atherosclerotic lesion formation. Our results provide a mechanistic understanding of the role of YAP/TAZ in the development of atherosclerotic lesions and suggest that inhibition of YAP/TAZ activation is a promising therapeutic strategy for the prevention of atherosclerosis. (Show more)

Wildfires are a natural part of many ecosystems, but in the United States they have become a significant threat to human life and property, as well as a major contributor to carbon emissions. We show that humans have expanded the geographic and seasonal extent of wildfire, and that this expansion has been driven by human activities. We highlight the need for increased management of human-started wildfires, which are the dominant cause of wildfire in the United States.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We use this method to show that three factors predict neighborhood improvement: the density of college-educated adults, the initial appearance of the neighborhood, and the proximity of the neighborhood to other attractive neighborhoods. These results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our results also have implications for the design of urban policy.

Natural repellents are a sustainable and ecological method of pest control. However, the molecular targets of these plant-derived compounds in arthropods remain to be further elucidated. Here, we identified a scorpion TRP channel as a receptor of natural repellents, which is absent in insects. This study provides a molecular target of natural repellents in arthropods, and may help the rational design of insect control strategy and in conserving biodiversity. It should also help the understanding of the arthropod–plant adaptation. View Full-Text

The recent outbreak of Zika virus has been associated with severe fetal abnormalities and neurological complications. The mechanisms of disease are not fully understood, but the role of the immune system in the pathogenesis of the disease is well established. Here we present a mathematical model of the within-host dynamics of ZIKV, allowing for characterization of the growth and clearance of ZIKV within individual macaques. We show that the model can be used to predict the effect of antiviral treatment on the time to clearance of the virus. We also show that the model can be used to predict the effect of the timing of treatment on the time to clearance of the virus. These predictions can be used to guide the development of treatment strategies. (Show more)

Coral reefs are the most diverse and biodiverse ecosystems on Earth. However, they are under threat from a variety of environmental stressors, including ocean warming and acidification, overfishing, and pollution. In this study, we show that the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis is driven by altered nutrient cycling during heat stress. Our results provide a missing link in our understanding of the environmental drivers of bleaching and may ultimately help uncover fundamental processes underpinning the functioning of endosymbioses in general. The intestinal epithelium is a complex barrier that protects the host from the environment and regulates nutrient absorption and immune responses. In this study, we show that the loss of BMP signaling in the intestinal epithelium leads to the development of intestinal tumors, which in turn activate a JNK-dependent feedback loop that drives the dysregulation of the microbiome and the development of tumors. Our findings identify a mechanism that links intestinal tumors to the microbiome, and they highlight the importance of controlling the activity level of JNK signaling to maintain the integrity of the intestinal epithelium and host–microbe homeostasis. These results have implications for the development of therapies to treat intestinal tumors and restore the integrity of the intestinal barrier. They also provide insights into the role of the microbiome in the development of intestinal tumors. Our study provides a mechanistic understanding of the role of the microbiome in the development of intestinal tumors and highlights the importance of controlling the activity level of JNK signaling to maintain the integrity of the intestinal epithelium and host–microbe homeostasis. Chemotherapy is the most common treatment for breast cancer, but the response to chemotherapy is heterogeneous, and many patients relapse. We show that chemotherapy can increase the expression of the type I tyrosine kinase-like orphan receptor ROR1, which is associated with the expression of genes that are important for the activation of Rho-GTPases, Hippo-YAP/TAZ, and BMI1. We also show that ROR1 is expressed in breast cancer patient-derived xenografts (PDXs), and that treatment of mice bearing PDXs with the humanized anti-ROR1 monoclonal antibody cirmtuzumab can reduce the number of PDXs and improve the response to chemotherapy. These results suggest that targeting ROR1 may improve the response to chemotherapy in patients with breast cancer. (Show more)

The start of deglaciation in the Southern Hemisphere is often attributed to a change in the position of the Southern Hemisphere westerly winds. We show that a volcanic eruption, which led to stratospheric ozone depletion, occurred exactly at the start of deglaciation. This eruption likely caused a change in the general circulation, which in turn led to changes in climate. Our results provide evidence for a role for stratospheric ozone depletion in the climate impacts of large volcanic eruptions. This is important for understanding the potential impacts of future large volcanic eruptions on climate. (Less)

Freshwater fisheries are a critical source of food, recreation, and commerce for hundreds of millions of people worldwide. However, they are often overlooked in conservation and management efforts. We provide a global map of riverine fisheries, which reveals that the majority of catches come from regions with high levels of human population density and river discharge. We also show that freshwater fisheries provide the equivalent of all dietary animal protein for 158 million people, highlighting the importance of inland fisheries for food security. Our analysis highlights the need for more sustainable management of river fisheries, particularly in regions where biodiversity is at risk.

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge, and aqueous Li-ion batteries draw large attention for this purpose. However, the energy density and the selection of negative electrode materials are significantly limited due to the narrow electrochemical stable potential window of aqueous electrolytes. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. The material delivers a large capacity of ∼170 mA ⋅ h ⋅ g−1 with a low operating potential range of 1.9 to 2.8 versus Li/Li+ in 21 m lithium bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)amide (LiTFSA) aqueous electrolyte. In this study, we identify a form of regeneration in the nervous system that is independent of the canonical MAPK signaling pathway. This form of regeneration is triggered by physical lesion of the neuron, and it is enhanced by disrupting calcium channels and elevating cAMP. We also find that this form of regeneration is linked to a well-studied form of endogenous activity-dependent ectopic axon outgrowth in the same neuron type. These findings suggest that this form of regeneration may be a powerful platform for gene discovery in neuronal regeneration. Moreover, we find that this form of regeneration is similar to lesion conditioning, a phenomenon producing robust regeneration in the mammalian CNS. Taken as a whole, our study unites disparate forms of neuronal outgrowth to uncover fresh molecular insights into activity-dependent control of the adult nervous system’s intrinsic regenerative capacity. The process of recombination is fundamental to the functioning of the genome, and its rate is a key factor in the evolution of a species. We have developed a method to precisely locate the boundaries of recombination events in a wild population of the monkeyflower Mimulus guttatus. This allows us to map the distribution of recombination across the genome, and to identify regions of the genome that are particularly active or inactive.

The resting state of the human brain is characterized by a complex network of functional interactions. Here, we show that the dominant component of the metabolic resting state network in healthy subjects is topographically similar to the default mode network. In Parkinson’s disease, the dominant component of the metabolic resting state network is topographically similar to a disease-related pattern. Network functionality was assessed by quantifying metabolic RSN expression in cerebral blood flow PET scans acquired at rest and during task performance. We found that the dominant component of the metabolic resting state network was deactivating in healthy subjects and early Parkinson’s disease patients, and that this abnormality was partially corrected by dopaminergic therapy. In contrast, in Alzheimer’s disease, the dominant component of the metabolic resting state network was deactivating at diagnosis, progressing over time. These results provide a direct link between the resting organization of the brain and its functional properties. They also provide a potential biomarker for the early diagnosis of Parkinson’s disease and for the assessment of the efficacy of dopaminergic therapy.

We have discovered a 5′ cap structure in yeast that is modified by nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NAD+). This cap is found on subsets of nuclear and mitochondrial encoded mRNAs, and is not found on the same transcripts that have the canonical 5′ cap structure. The 5′ NAD+ cap may play a role in regulating the stability and translation of specific subsets of mRNAs.

We show that epigenetic DNA-methylation differences at specific loci persist for several years during the long-term follow-up of the Diabetes Control and Complications Trial (DCCT) in people with diabetes. These epigenetic differences are associated with glycemia, and in vitro, high glucose induces similar persistent hypomethylation at the thioredoxin-interacting protein (TXNIP) locus in cultured human monocytes. These results support an epigenetic explanation for metabolic memory, the prolonged beneficial effects of intensive vs. conventional therapy during the DCCT on the progression of microvascular complications in the long-term follow-up.
This study provides a deeper understanding of the role of FSIP1 in the drug sensitivity of TNBC.

Alcohol dependence is a chronic disease that is difficult to treat. The present study shows that the gut barrier is altered in a significant proportion of alcohol-dependent subjects, and that this alteration is associated with the psychological symptoms of the disease. Moreover, the composition and activity of the gut microbiota are altered in these subjects. These results suggest that the gut microbiota is involved in the development of the gut barrier and in the psychological symptoms of alcohol dependence. Thus, the gut microbiota seems to be a previously unidentified target in the management of alcohol dependence.

The flavor of tomato fruit is a complex mixture of volatile organic compounds, which are responsible for the characteristic aroma. The biosynthesis of these compounds is not well understood, and the role of nitrogenous compounds in tomato flavor is unknown. Here, we report the discovery of a gene essential for the production of all the nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit. We also provide evidence that this gene is involved in the biosynthesis of a class of nitrogenous compounds that are not found in other plants. This work provides a foundation for the development of new strategies for improving the flavor of tomato fruit. (Show more)

We show that the impacts of global warming on ecosystem functioning are likely to be exacerbated by biodiversity loss. We demonstrate that the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning changes in response to temperature change, and that this change is driven by changes in the thermal tolerance curves of species. We also show that the contribution of complementarity to the net biodiversity effect increases at high and low temperatures, indicating that changes in species interactions play a critical role in mediating the impacts of temperature change on the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning. Our results highlight the need to consider the combined effects of global warming and biodiversity loss in the management of ecosystems. This is particularly important in light of the current rate of biodiversity loss and the rapid pace of global warming.

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a critical hub for the formation of spatial maps. However, the organization of its neurons is still poorly understood. Here, we used a portable two-photon microscope to record the activity of a large number of neurons in the MEC of freely moving mice. We found that grid cells, which are the main neurons for the formation of spatial maps, are strongly coupled among themselves, but have weaker links to other cell types. These results provide a detailed view of the organization of neurons in MEC and may help to elucidate the mechanisms underlying the formation of spatial maps. This article is protected by copyright. Flowering is a complex process, which is controlled by a large number of genes. In this study, we show that the flowering signal FT is not only important for the flowering of the host, but also for the flowering of the parasite. This study illustrates how regressive evolution, commonly found in parasites, may facilitate the physiological synchronization of parasite and host, here allowing the C. australis parasite to time reproduction exactly with that of their hosts, likely optimizing parasite fitness.

The dopamine system of the brain is critical to movement and motivation. We show that dopamine neurons in the substantia nigra, the primary site of dopamine cell loss in Parkinson’s disease, are not only connected to the striatum, the target of dopamine, but also to a specialized system of cells and fibers that are not part of the striatonigral pathway. These cells and fibers, here termed “striosome–dendron bouquets,” are likely critical to the function of dopamine in the brain.

We all know it when we feel it, but how do we know when two people are feeling connected to each other? We asked pairs of friends and strangers to talk with each other and rate their felt connection. For both friends and strangers, speed in response was a robust predictor of feeling connected. Conversations with faster response times felt more connected than conversations with slower response times, and within conversations, connected moments had faster response times than less-connected moments. This effect was determined primarily by partner responsivity: People felt more connected to the degree that their partner responded quickly to them rather than by how quickly they responded to their partner. The temporal scale of these effects (<250 ms) precludes conscious control, thus providing an honest signal of connection. Using a round-robin design in each of six closed networks, we show that faster responders evoked greater feelings of connection across partners. Together, these findings suggest that response times comprise a robust and sufficient signal of whether two minds “click.”

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the natural pacemaker of the heart. It is composed of specialized cardiomyocytes, the sinoatrial (SAN) cells, which are responsible for the generation of the heart rate. SAN cells are able to adjust heart rate to meet hemodynamic demand, but the molecular mechanisms that govern this process are not fully understood. Here, we report that stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1) is a key regulator of the heart rate in the SAN.

Silicon (Si) is an essential element for plant growth and development, but its role in plant defense against insect herbivores has not been well characterized. Here, we show that Si pretreatment of rice plants increases resistance against the rice leaffolder, a major insect pest of rice, and that this effect is mediated by the jasmonate (JA) signaling pathway. Our results suggest that Si and JA act in concert to promote plant defense against insect herbivores. This study provides a mechanism for the beneficial effects of Si on plant defense and may lead to the development of Si-based strategies for insect pest control. (Show more)
This study provides a new perspective on the role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism. It also provides a new target for the treatment of phenylketonuria.

Language is a complex system that requires the integration of information over time. Here we propose a mechanism for memory that is based on the adaptive changes in the excitability of neurons. We show that the dynamics of these changes can support memory on timescales ranging from milliseconds to seconds. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, which makes it suitable for temporal integration in sequence processing within the language domain. We believe that this work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

Plants are the most important source of food and medicine, and they are also the most important source of natural products. However, plants are difficult to genetically modify, and the delivery of biomolecules to plants is a major challenge. Here, we show that DNA nanostructures can be used to deliver biomolecules to plants, and we demonstrate that the size, shape, compactness, stiffness, and attachment location of the DNA nanostructures are important design parameters for plant cell internalization and gene silencing. Our work establishes the feasibility of biomolecule delivery to plants with DNA nanostructures and both details the design parameters of importance for plant cell internalization and also assesses the impact of DNA nanostructure geometry for gene silencing mechanisms. This work is a significant step forward in the development of plant biotechnology. (Show more)

Nutrient pollution is one of the most pervasive threats to aquatic ecosystems worldwide. In the United States, the majority of nutrient pollution comes from small, nonpoint sources, such as agricultural fields and urban areas. However, the role of small streams in driving coastal nutrient pollution has been largely overlooked. We show that small streams can be a significant source of nutrients to large water bodies, such as Lake Michigan. Our findings suggest that nutrient management efforts should focus on small streams, which can be more effective at delivering nutrients to coastal areas. This approach could help to reduce the ecological impacts of nutrient pollution on valuable nearshore ecosystems.

We study the dynamics of a simple chemical network in a thermodynamic environment that is only available to a small fraction of the possible chemical states. We find that the dynamics of the system are biased toward states that are extremized with respect to the environmental forcing.

The history of carbon (C) perturbation events throughout Earth’s history has provided key insights into how the Earth system responds to abrupt warming. Here, we present an integrated proxy (C and uranium [U] isotopes and paleo CO2) and multicomponent modeling approach to investigate an abrupt C perturbation and global warming event (∼304 Ma) that occurred during a paleo-glacial state. We report pronounced negative C and U isotopic excursions coincident with a doubling of atmospheric CO2 partial pressure and a biodiversity nadir. The isotopic excursions can be linked to an injection of organic matter–derived C over 300 kyr and to near 20% of areal extent of seafloor anoxia. Earth system modeling indicates that widespread anoxic conditions can be linked to enhanced thermocline stratification and increased nutrient fluxes during this global warming within an icehouse. This work provides a new perspective on the role of organic matter in the Earth system and the potential for anoxia to play a key role in global warming. (Less)

The palm oil industry is the largest consumer of deforestation-prone tropical peatlands in the world. We show that the certification of palm oil plantations can reduce the rate of forest loss in these areas. However, certification has no causal impact on forest loss in peatlands or active fire detection rates. Broader adoption of certification in forested regions, strict requirements to avoid all peat, and routine monitoring of clearly defined forest cover loss in certified and RSPO member-held plantations appear necessary if the RSPO is to yield conservation and climate benefits from reductions in tropical deforestation.

The exocytosis process is essential for the transport of molecules from the endoplasmic reticulum to the plasma membrane and the recycling of the endocytic vesicles to the plasma membrane. The exocyst complex is involved in the final steps of the exocytosis process. In this study, we discovered a small molecule that inhibits the exocytosis process in plants and humans. This study provides a valuable tool for studying the regulation of the exocytosis process and a potential target for drugs aimed at addressing human disease. (Show more)

In many vertebrates, sex is determined by a single gene, resulting in two sexes. In species with multiple sex determination alleles, the sex of an individual can be different from the sex of the species. We show that the cichlid fish Metriaclima mbenjii has four possible sexes, and that the sex of an individual is determined by the sex of the gene that it carries. We also show that the sex of an individual is not only determined by the sex of the gene, but also by the sex of the gene and the sex of the species.

The retina is a unique organ that is challenged by two distinct forms of reactive oxygen species. One is generated by the photochemistry of light, and the other is generated by the photochemistry of the retinal pigment epithelium. We show that the intracellular level of iron impacts the photochemistry of the retina, and that this impact is mediated by the photochemistry of the retinal pigment epithelium.

Predators are the main drivers of ecosystems, and the evolution of their feeding strategies is a key process in the development of food webs. However, the evolution of specialization is often considered a dead end, due to the constraints associated with the evolution of morphological and functional optimizations throughout the organism. Here we show that the evolution of siphonophore predators has been more flexible than previously thought, and that specialization can be maintained and even be linked to morphological evolution. Our findings contribute to understanding how specialization and morphological evolution have shaped present-day food webs. They also provide insights into the evolution of other predators, and may help to understand how the structure of food webs is shaped by the evolution of specialization.

The evolution of the human hand is a key area of research in human evolution. This study provides the earliest unambiguous evidence for the evolution of a key shared derived characteristic of modern human and Neandertal hand morphology.

Cancer is a disease of the cell cycle, and the cell cycle is fueled by the one-carbon donor, glycine. We have developed a small-molecule inhibitor of the enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase, which converts serine to glycine and a folate-bound one-carbon unit. We have used this inhibitor to identify a metabolic vulnerability of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma, a cancer that is notoriously difficult to treat. We have also identified a metabolic vulnerability of colon cancer, a cancer that is much easier to treat. Thus, we have identified a metabolic vulnerability of cancer that can be exploited for the treatment of cancer.

This study shows that deforestation can have a negative impact on people’s diets, and that this impact is exacerbated when forests are fragmented. The results have important implications for policy makers given that forests are largely overlooked in strategies to improve nutrition, but offer potential “win–wins” in terms of meeting nutrition goals as well as conservation and environmental goals. The results also highlight the need for a more holistic approach to food and nutrition security that considers the role of natural landscapes such as forests in meeting nutrition goals.

Modern farm machinery has greatly increased the capacity of agricultural production, but at the cost of higher vehicle weights that have led to compaction of the soil, which is a major threat to soil health and productivity. We show that the increase in vehicle weight has led to the propagation of compaction into deeper soil layers, which now exceed safe mechanical limits for soil ecological functioning. We developed a global map for delineating subsoil compaction susceptibility based on estimates of mechanization level, mean tractor size, soil texture, and climatic conditions. The alarming trend of chronic subsoil compaction risk over 20% of arable land, with potential loss of productivity, calls for a more stringent design of farm machinery that considers intrinsic subsoil mechanical limits. As the total weight of modern harvesters is now approaching that of the largest animals that walked Earth, a paradox emerges of potential prehistoric subsoil compaction. We hypothesize that unconstrained roaming of sauropods would have had similar adverse effects on land productivity as modern farm vehicles, suggesting that ecological strategies for reducing subsoil compaction, including fixed foraging trails, must have guided these prehistoric giants.
